name: Le Gray Beirut
description: AI Generated: Le Gray Beirut is a top-rated hotel in Lebanon.
scamWarning: Always confirm taxi prices before arriving.

topReviews.author: Antonio BH
topReviews.text:
My stay at Le Gray immediately after the soft opening was truly exceptional. From the warm reception to the smooth room check-in, every detail was handled with professionalism and care. The room itself was impeccable, beautifully prepared, spotlessly clean, and equipped with everything needed for a comfortable stay. The overall cleanliness of the hotel was equally impressive.

The staff are clearly well trained, attentive, and genuinely dedicated to creating a memorable guest experience.

I also had the chance to try the restaurant, where both the taste and quality of the dishes went far beyond my expectations. The cigar lounge was another highlight, a perfect blend of luxury and art that creates a very special atmosphere.

Finally, the location of the hotel is unbeatable. Situated in the heart of Beirut, everything worth visiting is just a few steps away.

topReviews.author: Pedro Javier Mart√≠nez
topReviews.text:
Excellent stay in the heart of Beirut.
Prime location near Downtown, restaurants, and nightlife.
Spacious rooms with refined design and strong sound insulation.
Comfortable beds and high quality linens.
Rooftop pool with panoramic city views.
Professional staff, attentive and efficient.
Solid breakfast with good variety.
A reliable choice for business or leisure stays.

topReviews.author: Kevin Saliba
topReviews.text:
Very disappointing experience.
I had reserved a gift room at Le Gray Beirut as a surprise for my friends who were getting married, expecting a high-end and professional experience worthy of such a special occasion. Unfortunately, the reality was the opposite.
The reception staff was unwelcoming and unhelpful, the service was disorganized, and there was zero attention to detail. We had to repeat ourselves multiple times, and the overall attitude felt careless and indifferent.
For a hotel that positions itself as luxury, the experience was extremely overpriced compared to the poor level of service provided. It was embarrassing, especially considering this was meant to be a memorable moment for newlyweds.
I would not recommend this hotel for special occasions. Expectations were high, but delivery was far below acceptable standards.

name: The Phoenicia Hotel
description: AI Generated: The Phoenicia Hotel is a top-rated accommodation in Lebanon.
scamWarning: Always confirm taxi prices before arriving.

topReviews.author: Kiriyaki
topReviews.text: I was at the Phoenicia InterContinental from December 14 to December 18, and I can honestly say this is one of the most impressive hotel experiences I've ever had. I don't usually remember names, but the service was so excellent that I have to give credit where it's due. At breakfast, the breakfast manager, Naji, took outstanding care of us and always made sure everything was perfect. A brilliant man who made every morning a delight, and the breakfast choices were incredible, diverse, delicious, and wonderfully presented. Room service was just as good. George was our room service operator and he was simply awesome. Every order was delivered swiftly, correctly, and to perfection; you can tell these people are professionals. It started at check-in. My eventual check-in attendant, Ala, checked me in and made it all 100% effortless with not a single issue. Efficient, welcoming, and incredibly well organized. The rest of the experience was just as noteworthy. The amenities are simply stunning. The sauna, steam room, pool, and impressive gym make this a well-rounded experience outside of just excellent service. I'm overall very surprised and extremely happy. The Phoenicia InterContinental really goes above and beyond; it feels like a well-oiled machine with world-class support and really well thought out amenities. I wouldn't hesitate to return nor recommend this to anyone.

topReviews.author: Jawad Hijazi
topReviews.text: Had such an amazing stay at the Phoenicia! You really can't beat the location the sea views are incredible and Zaituna Bay is just a quick walk away. The room was huge and spotless. The staff were honestly the highlight, though; they were so friendly and made us feel right at home. Breakfast was delicious. Definitely recommend if you're looking for a luxury spot in Beirut

topReviews.text: I visited the Phoenicia Hotel in Beirut last night, and the stay was fantastic. I truly enjoyed dinner at Cascade everything was excellent. ‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è If I could give 10 stars, I would.

name: Baalbek Restaurant
description: AI Generated: Baalbek Restaurant is a top-rated restaurant in Lebanon.
scamWarning: Always confirm taxi prices before arriving.

topReviews.author: Najib Ismael
topReviews.text:
Baalbek Restaurant is without a doubt one of the best dining spots in the area, offering an excellent combination of prime location, high standards of cleanliness, professional service, and outstanding food quality. From the moment you arrive, it is clear that attention to detail is a top priority from the welcoming atmosphere to the well-organized seating and overall presentation.

The service is courteous, efficient, and attentive, striking the right balance between being present and allowing guests to enjoy their meal comfortably. The food is prepared with fresh, high-quality ingredients, and the flavors are clean and well-defined. The seasoning is perfectly balanced neither overpowering nor bland allowing the natural taste of each dish to stand out.

With its consistent quality, inviting atmosphere, and excellent service, Baalbek is a restaurant you can confidently return to, whether for a casual meal or a special occasion.
Highly recommended for anyone seeking a refined and satisfying dining experience.

topReviews.author: Liliana Louro
topReviews.text:
The experience was great, with the staff being very attentive and helpful. We chose 6 different mezze to share among the three of us and they were all flavorful and we felt satiated enough. We have also picked two desserts and they were very tasty.
The atmosphere was nice and chill, but it was a Monday evening.
I would definitely recommend checking it out if you have the chance. Overall, it's a place worth visiting.

topReviews.author: √Åd√°m Kert√©sz
topReviews.text: I would definitely recommend Baalbek, even though it's not among my favourite oriental restaurants in Budapest. The dishes are quite unique, but they are quite overpriced when compared to the rather moderate or downright small amounts served. Do not expect a very intense culinary experience you will remember very long. The best items on the menu were the desserts (not many places offer authentic kunafa in Hungary), the Lebanese wines (also with rather aggressive pricing) and the signature cocktails. The helpful members of the staff are also worth mentioning, with particular regard to the charming ladies.

The restaurant offers a seated menu that is impressively rich, showcasing a variety of authentic Beirut flavors in every course. Every dish was thoughtfully prepared and beautifully presented, reflecting both quality and creativity.

Whether it was the perfectly spiced appetizers, the succulent main courses, or the delectable desserts, every bite left a lasting impression.

Overall, Karam Beirut Restaurant not only met but exceeded my expectations. It‚Äôs a fantastic spot for those looking to enjoy a memorable dining experience that combines the richness of Beirut‚Äôs culinary heritage with a welcoming atmosphere‚Äîtruly a gem during the holy month of Ramadan.

The menu celebrates authentic Levantine flavors with a refined contemporary twist. Three must-try dishes truly stand out:

The Fatt√© Makdous, creamy, rich, and bursting with flavor.

The vine leaves and lamb chops, tender, aromatic, and deeply comforting.

And the Kabab bil Karaz, a remarkable Aleppine specialty ‚Äî savory meat paired with the gentle sweetness of cherry sauce.

Each dish reflects a harmony of heritage and innovation, crafted with care and precision. The service is warm, professional, and attentive, perfectly complementing the ambiance.
Whether for a family gathering, an evening with friends, or a relaxed dinner, Naranj Caf√© offers a memorable taste of the Levant ‚Äî authentic, modern, and unmistakably Beirut.
And don‚Äôt forget to end your meal with their Em Narine Knefe ‚Äî a divine sweet finish that perfectly captures the soul of this place.

topReviews.author: Lara Noueihed
topReviews.text:
A Must-Visit Gem in Beirut

From the moment you walk in, the staff makes you feel like family‚Äîmore than welcoming, their warmth sets the tone for an unforgettable dining experience.

The food? Simply exceptional. Every dish is prepared with care, but the mohammara is a true highlight‚Äîrich, smoky, and perfectly spiced, it's easily one of the best I've tasted in Beirut.

And let‚Äôs talk about the bread: served hot, fresh out of the oven, it‚Äôs not just delicious‚Äîit‚Äôs unique. Perfect for dipping or enjoying on its own. It‚Äôs the kind of bread you keep reaching for throughout the meal.

Just when you think it can‚Äôt get any better, the desserts arrive. Whether you're into traditional Lebanese sweets or creative modern takes, every option is a beautifully crafted finale to an outstanding meal.

Beirut just got lucky with this new spot. Highly recommended.

topReviews.author: Sanaa Abdalla
topReviews.text: A new gem in Beirut! No other restaurant in town can match the unique levantine and exceptional food experience they offer. Every dish is full of flavor and quality. Definitely a must try spot for anyone who loves great food.

Deeply disappointing and discriminatory experience

I understand that security can refuse entry, but what happened at Grand Factory was pure prejudice. I was judged and turned away based on looks, with no explanation and no clear entry criteria ‚Äî despite being dressed decently and having been a regular visitor.

What makes it worse is that I reached out multiple times to clarify and resolve the issue, yet my messages and calls were completely ignored. This silence speaks volumes about how little the management cares about accountability or respect.

A place that calls itself inclusive and non-discriminatory should never treat people with such disdain and lack of basic human decency. Until this is addressed transparently, I won‚Äôt be returning ‚Äî and others deserve to know how this venue truly operates.

This intimate theatre offers a unique and enriching experience with a different show almost every night, ranging from music to theater and cabaret. We attended a brilliantly produced show that portrayed a street in 1960s Beirut known for its red-light district. The performance was a perfect blend of humor, storytelling, and cultural reflection. The actors were captivating, and the direction was sharp and engaging. The atmosphere was warm, inclusive, and full of artistic energy. Metro Al Madina is more than just entertainment ‚Äî it‚Äôs a celebration of Beirut‚Äôs rich, complex, and colorful identity. Whether you're a local or a visitor, it's a must-visit destination for anyone looking to experience the city‚Äôs creative spirit. An unforgettable night and a well-deserved five-star experience!

topReviews.author: Petra Samaha
topReviews.text: Metro used to be one of the rare safe, smoke-free places in Beirut where you could actually dance and enjoy great music, especially the Midnight Metro. It always felt like a space for people who wanted to have fun without being forced to breathe smoke. Unfortunately, yesterday we discovered they now allow smoking for the post-midnight gig. We had to leave, and we won‚Äôt be going back. Why change something that worked so well? For years, people who wanted to smoke could do it outside on the stairs while socializing and those who didn‚Äôt had the choice. It‚Äôs really disappointing to lose one of the few smoke-free nightlife spaces in the city. Not returning.. sad to see this place give up what made it inclusive.

description: AI Generated: Jbeil Beach is a top-rated beach in Lebanon.

topReviews.author: Freddy Makhoul
topReviews.text:
Enjoy the Beach for Free! üèñÔ∏è

Jbeil's public beach is a fantastic place where you can have a great time by yourself or with friends, and the best part is, it's completely free! It's one of the few activities in Lebanon that won't cost you anything.

The beach is always clean and safe thanks to the hard work of the Jbeil municipality. Lifeguards are also present to ensure everyone's safety.

As you approach the check-point, be prepared for an inspection by the municipality officer to ensure compliance with the "no alcohol" policy. While this may seem restrictive to some, it undoubtedly contributes to maintaining a family-friendly and peaceful atmosphere.

The water is clear and the view is amazing, making it a perfect spot to relax and have fun.

If you're driving, there's a parking area, but it's not free, so keep that in mind.

In conclusion, Jbeil's public beach is a wonderful place to spend a memorable day without spending any money. So, gather your things, enjoy the beautiful view, and have a fantastic time at the beach! üåäüèÑ

Jbeil's public beach is a fantastic place where you can have a great time by yourself or with friends, and the best part is, it's completely free! It's one of the few activities in Lebanon that won't cost you anything.

The beach is always clean and safe thanks to the hard work of the Jbeil municipality. Lifeguards are also present to ensure everyone's safety.

As you approach the check-point, be prepared for an inspection by the municipality officer to ensure compliance with the "no alcohol" policy. While this may seem restrictive to some, it undoubtedly contributes to maintaining a family-friendly and peaceful atmosphere.

The water is clear and the view is amazing, making it a perfect spot to relax and have fun.

If you're driving, there's a parking area, but it's not free, so keep that in mind.

In conclusion, Jbeil's public beach is a wonderful place to spend a memorable day without spending any money. So, gather your things, enjoy the beautiful view, and have a fantastic time at the beach! üåäüèÑ

Everything is perfect from the pools, to the amazing sand beach with its natural pool, to the ambiance, even waiters are great.
But because i love lazy b i will mention below my remarks.
-The place doesn't reflect the lebanese hospitality that is known for its generosity, 12$ for a sip of apperol and it doesn't even come with nuts? I literally never went to a place in lebanon that offers nothing with its drinks.
-Food and beverages are very overpriced for no reason, 5$ icecream that costs 0.5$ in retail shops! Sandwiches were very poor compared to price with no side salad or anything.
-Food Menu is very basic, even beverages they don't even have American coffee.
-20$ entrance for kids starting 2 years old!
-For the prices mentioned above which is their right to charge if it fits them, you would expect more luxurious treatment to the guests, at least a towel for example, soap in the showers, etc.. many things can be done.
I love Lazy B, i truly hope they take the remarks into consideration.

topReviews.text:
Beirut is the capital and largest city of Lebanon. As of 2014, Greater Beirut has a population of 2.4 million, which makes it the third-largest city in the Levant region. The city is situated on a peninsula at the midpoint of Lebanon's Mediterranean coast.
Beirut is Lebanon's seat of government and plays a central role in the Lebanese economy, with most banks and corporations based in its Central District, Badaro, Rue Verdun, Hamra, Ryad el Soloh street, and Ashrafieh.

Following the destructive Lebanese Civil War, Beirut's cultural landscape underwent major reconstruction. Identified and graded for accountancy, advertising, banking/finance and law, Beirut is ranked as a Beta World City by the Globalization and World Cities Research Network.

topReviews.text:
One of the most wonderful place I have ever visited‚Ä¶ thousands of years of history created drop by drop. Unfortunately pictures are not allowed inside the cave, but good side is that you will experience the first fresh emotions.

Technical information: cave has higher and lower part, higher part with amazing space inside, all walking in and back out. Lower part is on the water, little trip with boat, you should not miss. Connection between those two, as well as going back to parking is possible with small ‚Äútrain‚Äù. All those are included with one ticket, around 10$ for a person.

topReviews.author: Shaik Masood
topReviews.text: A natural wonder developped over millions of years inside the these beautiful mountains. A formation of Stalactites and Stalagmites, many in weird shapes such as Jelly Fish, Mushroom, etc. based on their shapes. There are 3 layers to visit, Upper, Middle and Lower. While Upper and Middle is on foot, the lower is on a short boat trip. The temperatures within are cool throughout the year, around 20degs, especially a relief in the hot summers. The Entrance fee is $15 and includes rides on a cable car, toy train and the boat. Staff is friendly. Photography is strictly prohibited and they go to lengths to stop it. The reasoning given behind it when questioned was unconvincing and the only reason I can think of it so to create a curiosity among people so that people visit it in person generating income. Nevertheless, a beautiful place to not miss in a life time

name: Monastery of St. Antonios Qozhaya
description: AI Generated: Monastery of St. Antonios Qozhaya is a top-rated hiking in Lebanon.

topReviews.author: Tony Reaidi
topReviews.text: One of the most beautiful monasteries and churches in world, due its unique architecture that blends into the mountainous landscape. It is built on a sheer of a cliff with several churches carved deep into the huge rocks of the cliff. The main church is a deeply holy place where you can meditate and with your prayers you can be transformed into the most holy of space and time.

topReviews.author: joseph saadeh
topReviews.text:
The Monastery of Saint Anthony the Great (Deir Mar Antonios Qozhaya) in the Kadisha Valley, Lebanon, has an ancient history of monasticism, first occupied by hermits in the 4th century and later becoming home to the Lebanese Maronite Order.

Renowned for its Grotto of Saint Anthony, which is believed to be a place of miracles and cures, the monastery has been a vital spiritual center, a refuge, and housed the first printing press in the Middle East in 1610.

It has faced numerous challenges, including natural disasters and periods of persecution, but has been continuously restored and remains a significant pilgrimage site for Maronites globally.

topReviews.author: mahmoud kaddoura
topReviews.text:
We visited the Maronite Monastery of St. Anthony during Easter, and the place was lively and filled with people. The atmosphere was beautiful and festive. We also explored the museum below, which offered a glimpse into the history of Christianity‚Äîit‚Äôs a great experience for anyone interested in learning about other religions. I personally really enjoyed it.

The monastery‚Äôs location is stunning‚Äînestled between the mountains, with a nearby hiking trail and a river close by. I highly recommend visiting. There‚Äôs no entrance fee, and the road leading to it is scenic and truly transports you to another world.

topReviews.author: Farid Kamar
topReviews.text:
Beiteddine is absolutely worth a visit. I went with my kids, and it turned into a great opportunity for them to connect with their country's heritage in a real and memorable way.
The palace itself is stunning some rooms and details truly take your breath away. The architecture and design are a beautiful glimpse into Lebanon's past.
There are a few things that could make the experience even better: improved lighting and air-conditioning would go a long way, and having more guides or clearer descriptions would help visitors appreciate the site even more.
All in all, a great cultural outing for families or anyone interested in Lebanese history.

topReviews.author: Tahsine Reda
topReviews.text:
Beit el-Din in the Chouf is one of Lebanon‚Äôs most iconic landmarks, deeply rooted in history and always attracting visitors from near and far. Walking through its courtyards and halls gives a real sense of heritage and tradition.

At the same time, some areas could use more care. The furniture in the exhibition rooms feels worn and in need of restoration.

Even with these details, the palace remains a proud symbol of Lebanese history and culture worth visiting, reflecting upon, and preserving for future generations.

name: The Temple of Bacchus
description: AI Generated: The Temple of Bacchus is a top-rated historical_site in Lebanon.
scamWarning: Always confirm taxi prices before arriving.

topReviews.author: Julia Tran
topReviews.text: The Temple of Bacchus is truly incredible. Built around the 2nd century AD and dedicated to Bacchus, the Roman god of wine, it‚Äôs one of the best-preserved and largest Roman temples in the world..actually bigger than the Parthenon in Athens! The scale is incredible, with towering columns (almost 20 meters high) and beautifully detailed carvings. The whole site is quiet and not crowded, so you can really take your time exploring and taking photos. Walking through it feels like stepping back in time. Absolutely worth the trip if you‚Äôre visiting Baalbek or Lebanon.

topReviews.author: Ali Talib
topReviews.text: Baalbek Citadel ‚Äì An amazing archaeological site showcasing the grandeur of Roman civilization. The massive temples and intricate architecture make it a must-visit for history and culture lovers.

topReviews.author: Elizabeth Ayoub
topReviews.text: Each time I visit our beloved temple of Bacchus in Baalbek I am reminded of my transformations throughout the seasons of my life. It humbles me like few other places I have experienced. I first visited the temples with my late father who wanted to give me this incredible experience for the first time when I went to Lebanon as a younger woman. My wish for you is that it humbles you as well. Be still, quiet and let its magic envelop you.

topReviews.author: Fahd Batayneh ŸÅŸáÿØ ÿ®ÿ∑ÿßŸäŸÜÿ©
topReviews.text:
A fascinating museum inside the American University of Beirut; one of the oldest academic institutes in the region.

The museum is inside the university premises, and so one has to enter the university from the main gate, show a physical ID and keep it with the security folks, and then enter the premises to head to the museum. It is a quick process.

The museum spans over 2 floors showing different parts of the history of this land. Entrance is free.

Taking pictures inside the museum is prohibited.

The picture in this post is at the entrance of the museum, and I was allowed to take it. It is a trunk of a cedar tree.

Expect to spend 30 minutes onwards inside the museum. It is well organized and easy to navigate through.

topReviews.author: Carolyn
topReviews.text: We tried to visit the archeological museum, which is inside AUB's campus. When we got to the entrance, the security man told us we were supposed to email the museum ahead of time to ask if we could come, and we had to enter through the main entrance, not the one we were at. He even had the museum staff on the phone but we were still not permitted without sending an email. On the museum's website, it says to send an email prior to your visit IF you want a guided tour, not if you want to visit in general. Thus, we were unable to visit and overall it was a very disappointing experience. The website needs to be updated if this is really how they're doing museum admission now.

topReviews.author: Anderson England
topReviews.text: This museum is admittedly dwarfed by the National Museum but if it was in any other city around the world it would be a prized possession.  The artifacts and sculptures are displayed chronologically.  The amount of glass were and ceramic were in good condition is amazing. Very good descriptions and collection. One is not overwhelmed. Be sure and visit the Geological dusplays at the adjacent Department of Geology. Both museums are free of charge. Located on the verdant grounds of the historic American University of Beirut.

Technical information: cave has higher and lower part, higher part with amazing space inside, all walking in and back out. Lower part is on the water, little trip with boat, you should not miss. Connection between those two, as well as going back to parking is possible with small ‚Äútrain‚Äù. All those are included with one ticket, around 10$ for a person.

topReviews.author: Shaik Masood
topReviews.text: A natural wonder developped over millions of years inside the these beautiful mountains. A formation of Stalactites and Stalagmites, many in weird shapes such as Jelly Fish, Mushroom, etc. based on their shapes. There are 3 layers to visit, Upper, Middle and Lower. While Upper and Middle is on foot, the lower is on a short boat trip. The temperatures within are cool throughout the year, around 20degs, especially a relief in the hot summers. The Entrance fee is $15 and includes rides on a cable car, toy train and the boat. Staff is friendly. Photography is strictly prohibited and they go to lengths to stop it. The reasoning given behind it when questioned was unconvincing and the only reason I can think of it so to create a curiosity among people so that people visit it in person generating income. Nevertheless, a beautiful place to not miss in a life time

topReviews.author: Oliver Scott
topReviews.text: Byblos Citadel is an incredible historical site with exceptional archaeological variety. The preservation is outstanding, showcasing more than 8,000 years of continuous history from different civilizations. Walking through the ruins gives a real sense of the city‚Äôs deep past and cultural layers. A must-see for anyone interested in history or archaeology.

topReviews.author: Shaik Masood
topReviews.text: Such a wonderful historical site having influences of Roman, Phoenician and Ottoman periods. It was supposedly layered in soil and lost in time until recently when the residents were evacuated and the site excavated to find this lovely history. A mere visit to this site itself is all worthwhile with the beautiful breathtaking views of the Mediterranean sea. Take a guide along to learn history, it's worth it. You could easily spend around 2hrs wandering and around. Entrance fee is LBP800,000 ($9) and includes a visit a tiny museum within

topReviews.author: manuel bacha
topReviews.text: It is disappointing to see how badly maintained the place is. There is so much wasted potential in this place if only the ministry of tourism would put a bit of effort into it. The citadel itself is pretty nice, but the area around is becoming a grassland and a graveyard for the ancient pillars which are still in good condition. With a bit of work, they have all the pieces necessary to recreate some of the original structures. They also let exposed ancient mosaics in the middle of the bushes which you would mistakenly walk on and damage. The posters are covered with bird droppings that have not been removed for a long time. The visit was still worth it, but to see how badly we take care of our heritage is saddening.

There's a playground section for kids and it was pretty occupied so I can assume it's still a great place for parents to take their kids to.

The park also accommodates bicycles and scooters with a lane that loops around the park, so if you've got one or rented one, it'd be a pretty enjoyable ride!

topReviews.author: Georges Younes
topReviews.text: Calling this place a park is a stretch of the imagination. This area was developed recently, but it is far from becoming the park that it was designed to become. There are wide boulevards that are still quite empty because they go nowehre. There are patches of empty land all around the area that are supposed to host modern buildings or to be turned into open green spaces. All of them have been abandoned to their fate by the brutal economic crisis that Lebanon is facing. That said, the area has potential and great views on the city's downtown core and the mountains beyond. Come here for a walk or a jog or a bicycle ride.

topReviews.author: George A N
topReviews.text: One of the most beautiful Maronite cathedral  in Lebanon . It was destroyed during the civil war and it was extremely damaged . It was rebuilt after the civil war with the help of many faithful Maronite believers.we have attended the midnight mass for Easter and it was so beautiful. This cathedral is a surviving proof how resilient the Christian people specially Maronite and how important they were in the history of Beirut .

topReviews.author: Georges Younes
topReviews.text: Originally built in the second half of the nineteenth century, Saint George Maronite Cathedral was renovated in the middle of the twentieth, badly damaged during the Lebanese Civil War (1975-1990), then restored to its original designs in the late 20th century. Those designs were inspired by the Cathedral of Santa Maria Maggiore in Rome. The church's grounds are surrounded by much older remains of structures from the Hellenistic, Roman and Byzantine periods that were discovered during excavations that took place starting in the 1960s. After visiting the interior, go behind the cathedral for a better appreciation of its scale and surroundings.

topReviews.author: Shaik Masood
topReviews.text: One of the most beautiful and biggest mosques in Lebanon built in the Turkish style architecture with 4 minarates and a massive blue dome. Just beside is the St. George Cathedral, adding to it's beauty. The mosque is located opposite the Square. As beautiful as it looks from the outside, the inside is breathtaking, especially the huge chandeliers and the Islamic calligraphy lit by some good lighting. Entry is restricted to only at the 5 times of prayers. But sadly, as with any other mosque here, the mosques are usually empty even at the times of prayers/salaah. While I was there, even the first row/saff was not complete.

The mosque is adjacent to a few churches and the martyrs square. The Lebanese flag pole is on the other side of the road. The Beirut Souk is within walking distance.

Entering the mosque is free, but clothing appropriately is required. Worth spending no more than 15 minutes here.

topReviews.author: Georges Younes
topReviews.text: Our Lady of Balamand is an old Eastern Orthodox monastery with a rich history dating back to the mid-12th century. Beautifully restored and kept by the Antiochian order, it is worth the hour and a half that it will take you to reach it if you drive from Beirut. If you are staying in Tripoli, the monastery is a short drive away. If you are lucky, one of the monks will take you around and show you beautiful icons from different icon painting schools. I visited three different churches on the premises. If one of them is closed, ask the keepers to open the doors for you. Take the time to check the terrace behind the monastery. On a clear day, you can easily see Tripoli.

topReviews.author: Mariam Bughadze
topReviews.text:
One of the most wonderful place I have ever visited‚Ä¶ thousands of years of history created drop by drop. Unfortunately pictures are not allowed inside the cave, but good side is that you will experience the first fresh emotions.

Technical information: cave has higher and lower part, higher part with amazing space inside, all walking in and back out. Lower part is on the water, little trip with boat, you should not miss. Connection between those two, as well as going back to parking is possible with small ‚Äútrain‚Äù. All those are included with one ticket, around 10$ for a person.

topReviews.author: Shaik Masood
topReviews.text: A natural wonder developped over millions of years inside the these beautiful mountains. A formation of Stalactites and Stalagmites, many in weird shapes such as Jelly Fish, Mushroom, etc. based on their shapes. There are 3 layers to visit, Upper, Middle and Lower. While Upper and Middle is on foot, the lower is on a short boat trip. The temperatures within are cool throughout the year, around 20degs, especially a relief in the hot summers. The Entrance fee is $15 and includes rides on a cable car, toy train and the boat. Staff is friendly. Photography is strictly prohibited and they go to lengths to stop it. The reasoning given behind it when questioned was unconvincing and the only reason I can think of it so to create a curiosity among people so that people visit it in person generating income. Nevertheless, a beautiful place to not miss in a life time

Lower one wasn't much   water is nice but too much fuss over short boat trip

name: Khalil Gibran Memorial
description: AI Generated: Khalil Gibran Memorial is a top-rated religious_site in Lebanon.
scamWarning: Always confirm taxi prices before arriving.

topReviews.author: Indra S. Karki
topReviews.text:
These sculptures are of Khalil Gibran sculpted to appear as part of a tree in the woods by Gordon S. Kray.

Kahlil Gibran was a poet and philosopher born in 1883 in a village of  Besharri of Lebanon who was very much loved and inspired by his mother. He emigrated to Boston at young age and began his career as artist and author.

His books contain his mystical paintings and wrote both in Arabic and English and his books are translated in many languages and circulated  widely.
He passed away in New York City in 1931.

This memorial was designed by architect Hellmuth Obata and Kassabaum and was dedicated to the people of the United States by Kahlil Gibran Centennial Foundation in 1991.

Those who know Kahlil Gibran through his literature, are reminisced by being at this site.

topReviews.author: Joe Segal
topReviews.text: The memorial is tasteful, private, understated, and quiet. A nice place to read a chapter of your book.

I had an unforgettable experience at City Centre Beirut that truly deserves recognition. I accidentally lost an envelope containing $2,000 while inside the mall. After searching everywhere and coming up empty, I left feeling very discouraged.

To my surprise, just one hour later, I received a call from the mall‚Äôs management ‚Äî they had found the envelope and returned it to me with everything intact! I was honestly overwhelmed with happiness and gratitude.

This level of honesty, professionalism, and care from the staff and security team speaks volumes about the integrity of City Centre Beirut. Not only is it a top shopping and entertainment destination, but it‚Äôs also a place where you feel safe and respected.

A huge thank you to the entire team ‚Äî your efforts were truly appreciated. I highly recommend City Centre Beirut to everyone!

topReviews.author: Kareeem
topReviews.text:
City Centre Beirut is one of my go-to malls in the city, and I usually visit twice a month. It offers a great variety of dress stores, with almost all the famous international and local brands available, making it perfect for shopping sprees or gift hunting. The restaurants area is also a highlight‚Äîthere are plenty of options to choose from, and I always ask about promotions because you can find really good food at surprisingly cheap prices.

For families, the kids‚Äô arcade located on the first floor is a solid spot. My children enjoy it every time, and the prices are fairly reasonable compared to other places. It‚Äôs a good way to keep them entertained while I relax or shop.

Parking is another plus‚Äîthere are multiple floors for parking, so I rarely struggle to find a spot, even on weekends. The mall is clean, spacious, and well-organized, and the overall vibe is comfortable whether you‚Äôre there to shop, eat, or just hang out.

All in all, City Centre Beirut is a solid choice if you‚Äôre looking for variety, convenience, and a family-friendly environment. It‚Äôs definitely one of the better malls in Lebanon.

Beirut is the capital and largest city of Lebanon. As of 2014, Greater Beirut has a population of 2.4 million, which makes it the third-largest city in the Levant region. The city is situated on a peninsula at the midpoint of Lebanon's Mediterranean coast.
Beirut is Lebanon's seat of government and plays a central role in the Lebanese economy, with most banks and corporations based in its Central District, Badaro, Rue Verdun, Hamra, Ryad el Soloh street, and Ashrafieh.

Following the destructive Lebanese Civil War, Beirut's cultural landscape underwent major reconstruction. Identified and graded for accountancy, advertising, banking/finance and law, Beirut is ranked as a Beta World City by the Globalization and World Cities Research Network.

name: Baalbek International Festival
description: AI Generated: Baalbek International Festival is a top-rated activity in Lebanon.
scamWarning: Always confirm taxi prices before arriving.

topReviews.author: armaghan butt
topReviews.text:
Baalbek Roman Ruins ‚Äì Temple of Jupiter

Nestled in the fertile Beqaa Valley at the foothills of the Anti-Lebanon mountains, the ruins of Baalbek are among the most awe-inspiring archaeological sites in the world. At its heart once stood the Temple of Jupiter, the largest temple ever built in the Roman Empire and one of the grandest religious structures of antiquity.

Originally, Baalbek was a sacred site long before Roman rule, revered by Phoenicians who worshipped the sky god Baal. When the Romans took control in the 1st century BCE, they transformed the city‚Äîrenamed Heliopolis‚Äîinto a monumental religious complex. Construction of the Temple of Jupiter began around the 1st century CE and continued for more than two centuries.

The temple was built on a colossal stone podium, using some of the largest cut stones ever quarried and moved by humans. Nearby lies the famous Trilithon, three massive limestone blocks weighing around 800‚Äì1,000 tons each, a feat of engineering that still puzzles historians and engineers today.

At its height, the Temple of Jupiter featured:
‚Ä¢	54 colossal Corinthian columns, each about 22 meters (72 feet) high
‚Ä¢	A vast elevated platform dominating the landscape
‚Ä¢	Lavish decoration reflecting imperial Roman power

Only six columns remain standing today, but even these convey the overwhelming scale and ambition of the structure.

Transformation Through Religions and Empires
‚Ä¢	With the spread of Christianity in the 4th‚Äì5th centuries, the temple complex was partially dismantled, and a Christian basilica was constructed in the courtyard rather than inside the pagan temple‚Äîsymbolizing the transition from pagan worship.
‚Ä¢	Following the Arab-Muslim conquest in the 7th century, Baalbek became a fortified site. The ruins were adapted into an Islamic fortress (qal‚Äòa), serving defensive and administrative purposes over successive Islamic dynasties.

Historical Significance
‚Ä¢	The Temple of Jupiter is widely regarded as the largest Roman temple ever constructed, surpassing even those in Rome itself.
‚Ä¢	Baalbek reflects layers of civilization: Phoenician, Roman, Byzantine Christian, and Islamic.
‚Ä¢	Today, the site is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, celebrated for its architectural, religious, and engineering legacy.

The fallen pillars and scattered stones are not merely ruins‚Äîthey are silent witnesses to millennia of human belief, ambition, and adaptation, standing as one of the greatest achievements of the ancient world.

topReviews.author: Jakub Jurkiewicz
topReviews.text: One of the best tourist attractions in the whole Lebanon. Huge Roman ruins preserved in great condition. It's a must see for every history enjoyer visiting Lebanon.

topReviews.author: Axel
topReviews.text: Absolutely awe-inspiring place ‚Äî standing among the ruins of Baalbek feels like walking inside a forgotten myth. The sheer scale of the Temple of Jupiter and the precision of the stones leave you speechless. You can almost feel the history vibrating in the air. Go early morning or near sunset for dramatic light and fewer crowds. A must-see for anyone who loves ancient history, architecture, or mystery.

topReviews.author: Dani Baal
topReviews.text: The Tyre World Heritage Site in Lebanon is a remarkable blend of ancient history and coastal beauty. Its Roman ruins, including a hippodrome, aqueducts, and mosaics, showcase the city‚Äôs rich past, while the nearby beaches add a scenic touch. Walking through the site feels like stepping back in time, with well-preserved structures and informative displays. A must-visit for history enthusiasts and anyone wanting to experience Lebanon‚Äôs archaeological treasures.

topReviews.author: Shira ib
topReviews.text:
The Tyre World Heritage Site is an extraordinary destination that offers a deep dive into the rich history of one of the oldest cities in the world. As a UNESCO World Heritage Site, Tyre is renowned for its well preserved archaeological treasures, including the ancient Roman Hippodrome, the Necropolis, and the Egyptian Port.
Walking through the site, you can explore the remnants of Phoenician, Roman, and Byzantine civilizations. The Hippodrome, with its grand stands and detailed carvings, is particularly impressive and gives a sense of the grandeur of ancient chariot races. The Necropolis, with its intricate tombs and monuments, offers a poignant glimpse into the past!

topReviews.text: I was at the Phoenicia InterContinental from December 14 to December 18, and I can honestly say this is one of the most impressive hotel experiences I've ever had. At breakfast, the breakfast manager, Naji, took outstanding care of us and always made sure everything was perfect. A brilliant man who made every morning a delight, and the breakfast choices were incredible, diverse, delicious, and wonderfully presented. Room service was just as good. George was our room service operator and he was simply awesome. Every order was delivered swiftly, correctly, and to perfection; you can tell these people are professionals. It started at check-in. My eventual check-in attendant, Ala, checked me in and made it all 100% effortless with not a single issue. Efficient, welcoming, and incredibly well organized. The rest of the experience was just as noteworthy. The amenities are simply stunning. The sauna, steam room, pool, and impressive gym make this a well-rounded experience outside of just excellent service. I'm overall very surprised and extremely happy. The Phoenicia InterContinental really goes above and beyond; it feels like a well-oiled machine with world-class support and really well thought out amenities. I wouldn't hesitate to return nor recommend this to anyone.

topReviews.author: Houssam Mansour
topReviews.text:
Albergo is a beautiful boutique hotel cozy, old, and authentic, yet at the same time vibrant and full of character. The location is excellent, with nice restaurants and bar, which adds to the overall experience.

Check-in was very good, with pleasant and professional staff. One small opportunity for improvement would be a short introduction to the hotel facilities at arrival, which would enhance the first impression even more. It would also be lovely to see team members proactively greeting guests passing by elevators, as this would add an extra touch of warmth.

Service in the restaurants and outlets was good and well organized. All team members were friendly and helpful; however, a genuine smile was generally missing across the team. The service is there, the professionalism is there adding more visible smiles would instantly elevate the guest experience and make it feel warmer and more welcoming.

Breakfast was good and enjoyable.

The room was fantastic a Junior Suite with beautiful old-style, rustic interior design. The bathroom was large, the bed very comfortable, and the overall space elegant and cozy. Using the old-style elevator is a charming experience and adds to the hotel‚Äôs unique character.

The interior design: rooms, restaurants, bars, and rooftop is cozy, old, rustic, and authentic. The rooftop in particular feels intimate and timeless.

Overall: A great hotel, absolutely deserving to be called luxury. Great staff, good food, and beautiful design.

Suggestions: Nothing major just a lack of consistent smiles and proactive greetings from the team, and a brief introduction to the hotel facilities at check-in would have enhanced the experience. Given the small size of the hotel (30+ suites), remembering guests and greeting them by name would be easy to implement and would elevate service impact and guest satisfaction to another level. A quick courtesy call to the room after check-in to ensure everything is in order would further enhance the boutique experience and level of service.

Date of stay:
December 2025

topReviews.author: Ilda Nahas
topReviews.text:
üéâ Great event by the NGO Elas at Le Royal in Le Royal Hotel - Dbayeh.
The food was beautifully presented, very tasty, and clearly prepared with care. Service was good, just a bit slow. But you really can‚Äôt beat the superb location ‚Äî elegant venue, easy access, and a fantastic atmosphere. Overall, a lovely experience, especially for the senses! üåø

topReviews.author: Lilyann Schmidt
topReviews.text:
I recently stayed at this hotel, and I cannot express how disappointed I am. From start to finish, the experience was frustrating and unpleasant.

- Stinky Pillows and Ashtray Smell: The pillows reeked, and the room itself had a lingering odor reminiscent of an ashtray. It was unbearable and made it hard to relax.

- Stolen Water Bottles: I had a case of six water bottles go missing, and despite asking, I never received a single bottle by my bed. Housekeeping clearly took them because only them had access to my room.
- If you need extra towels, prepare to beg for them. It‚Äôs ridiculous that something so basic is such a hassle.

- Unhelpful Staff: The valet staff seemed more interested in staring than assisting. When my hands were full, I expected at least a little courtesy in opening the car door or a helping hand.

- Sample-Size Toiletries: The shampoo and conditioner were in tiny sample-sized bottles. When I requested more for 2 people, I felt like I was asking for a favor rather than what should be standard.
Whoever is managing this hotel needs to travel and stay at a ‚Äú5 stars hotel‚Äù and take notes of the differences!

Gym Facilities:
- Lack of Basic Amenities: There were no trash cans or available towels in the gym. I had to trek 3 floors up just to ask for one small towel or one large towel‚Äînever both at once! You would also expect at a ‚Äú5 stars hotel‚Äù to have apples, bananas, protein bars and protein drinks available. But NO! There wasn‚Äôt any!

Pool Experience:
- Dark and Uninviting: The water in the pool was murky and off-putting. It didn‚Äôt seem clean or safe for swimming.

Molds in the walls, very poorly maintained!

The only positive thing I found about this hotel is the location and the view. The architecture is also great but the place is definitely poorly maintained which made it look outdated

Save your money and find somewhere else to stay!

topReviews.author: Andreas Younan

Our stay at Le Royal Hotel Beirut  the last 7 days was absolutely exceptional! From the moment we arrived until the day we left, every member of the staff was incredibly kind, professional, and welcoming to our whole family.

A special thank you to Marwan Auchi for taking such great care of us from day one ‚Äî your warm hospitality and attention to detail truly made our experience unforgettable.And our Amazing Room was incredible thanks for the upgrade.

The hotel itself is stunning ‚Äî perfectly located with breathtaking views, modern and spacious rooms, and every facility you could wish for. The pool area, spa, and water area were top-notch, and the kids absolutely loved spending time there!

Breakfast was outstanding ‚Äî a delicious and varied selection every morning that we all looked forward to.

We can‚Äôt thank the team enough for making our family vacation so memorable. We‚Äôll definitely be coming back and highly recommend Le Royal Beirut to anyone visiting Lebanon

This was my second stay at your property. During my first stay, a paid service (room decoration) was not delivered. Instead of receiving a proper apology, the front desk agent explained it as ‚Äúhuman error.‚Äù While I understand that mistakes happen, the service was ultimately only refunded, with no effort to acknowledge the inconvenience or make amends.

topReviews.author: Aleen Saba
topReviews.text:
Exceptional Booking Service, but Serious Hygiene, Safety, and Service Failures
‚ÄãI stayed at the Ramada by Wyndham Lebanon from Dec 24‚Äì25. While the initial booking process was excellent thanks to Amira, who was professional and helpful in securing our connected executive and standard rooms, the actual stay was very disappointing.

‚ÄãThe Issues:

‚ÄãHygiene: I requested two cribs for my 7-month-old and 2-year-old. Not only were they not ready upon arrival, but when they were brought up, they were visibly dirty (specifically the green one). For infants, hygiene is non-negotiable. ‚ÄãStaff Communication: Despite prior confirmation for an extra bed for our helper, the floor staff insisted it was impossible. It took unnecessary debating to get what was already promised. ‚ÄãSafety Hazard: On the morning of the 25th, a strong burning electrical smell came from the bathroom lights. This is a major safety concern, especially when staying with young children. ‚ÄãThe Sweets Incident: This was the most upsetting part. We checked in 2.5kg of specialty Christmas sweets for storage. Upon checkout, we were told the staff "accidentally" served our sweets at the breakfast buffet. A staff member tried to pay us out of his own pocket to keep the hotel from finding out. This left us empty-handed for a Christmas lunch invitation with no time to buy a replacement.

‚ÄãThe lack of coordination and the safety/hygiene standards were not what I expected from the Wyndham brand.

‚ÄãResponse:

As i can't add a response anymore I'm editing my comment here for you.
I am writing to firmly clarify the facts regarding the recent incident involving our dessert. The account provided in your previous message contains several significant inaccuracies that need to be addressed immediately.
‚ÄãFirst, regarding the item: it was indeed knefe with soiree bread, a specialty item made only upon request and not available for daily purchase. Contrary to your records, this was purchased in Zahle, not Shtoura. You may verify this directly with the sweet shop. (And still this doesn't make it any less or extra important, it was ours and need to take whatever it was)

‚ÄãRegarding the resolution process, I must correct the following points:

‚ÄãLack of Management Oversight: The team member involved explicitly stated he was acting on his own "personal responsibility." At no point did a manager approach us to apologize or oversee the situation. Even though their was no previous notice, we were informed few minutes before leaving the hotel which makes it more and more unprofessional.
Furthermore, I find it alarming that your response treats it as standard procedure for a staff member to simply hand $45 in cash to a guest at their car without a single manager or supervisor appearing to address the error. Is this truly the professional image and 'transparency' your hotel aims to project? In any reputable establishment, a service failure of this nature is handled by management, not settled on the sidewalk by a staff member acting alone.

‚ÄãResolution Claims: No replacement was ever arranged, nor was any meaningful assistance offered beyond the basic reimbursement.

‚ÄãStaff Conduct: While we appreciated the warm initial welcome and the professionalism of Amira (who was the only truly helpful staff member), the subsequent handling of this issue by the rest of the team was unacceptable.
‚ÄãAs frequent international travelers‚Äîmy husband being a doctor and myself an architect‚Äîwe have high expectations for branded hotels. We have never encountered this level of misinformation regarding a service failure.

‚ÄãI strongly urge you to review your security footage and internal communications.
There is a clear lack of transparency in the report you received from your team. We expect a higher standard of accountability and honesty from an establishment of your reputation.

topReviews.author: Kees Kuijl
topReviews.text: The service was good, they provided extra service by letting us enter a lot earlier to our room than the checkin time, which was of great help for us. Location is at 10 minute walking distance to the old city centre of Jounieh. I don't know if this is normal in Lebanon but the room smelled a bit like there has been smoked inside of it, this could be taken into consideration.

topReviews.author: Miriam Ad
topReviews.text: Our recent stay at the AlMurjan Palace Hotel was thoroughly enjoyable and exceeded our expectations in several key areas. The hotel staff consistently demonstrated a high level of professionalism, friendliness, and helpfulness throughout our visit. Also, our room was spacious, tastefully decorated, and well-appointed with all necessary amenities, including complimentary Wi-Fi, a mini-fridge, a water kettle, a safe, and a selection of toiletries. Furthermore, we particularly appreciated the hotel's accommodating nature; upon our request, they graciously decorated our room in anticipation of Valentine's Day, adding a thoughtful and personalized touch to our stay. Moreover, the breakfast offerings were both delicious and varied. In addition, the hotel's convenient location offers easy access to local attractions. The Jounieh Public Park, ideal for walking, exercising, or jogging, is within walking distance and the cable car to Our Lady of Lebanon in Harissa is just a short drive away. Finally, we would like to express our sincere gratitude to the entire team at the AlMurjan Palace Hotel for their exceptional service and for making our stay so memorable.

topReviews.author: Yehya JB
topReviews.text:
I want to express my heartfelt gratitude to Al Murjan team for taking such great care of my parents, especially my mom, Roba, during the recent war in Lebanon. Accommodating them for an entire month with kindness and unmatched generosity made all the difference in such a difficult time.

One thing that truly stood out was the generosity in the breakfast offerings. Every morning, my parents were welcomed with a variety of delicious options that brought them comfort and joy, making them feel at home despite being far away. The thoughtfulness and care in every detail did not go unnoticed.

The staff‚Äôs compassion, professionalism, and attention to their well-being were remarkable. Thank you for providing safety, warmth, and nourishment when it was most needed. We will always remember your kindness, and I highly recommend Al Murjan for anyone seeking a place that truly cares about its guests.
